author: @peterkoppelman6232
text: Great stuff...I'm running python 3.62 on a windows 10 machine. I found that python prefers that the code to insert into a table be written as follows:      unix = time.time()     datestamp = time.strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')     keyword = 'Python'     value = random.randrange(0,10)     params = (unix, datestamp, keyword, value)     c.execute("INSERT INTO stuffToPlot VALUES (?,?,?,?)",params)

author: @fabioampe
text: (Not being rude :^] ) You happen to mention that the way sqlite handles the insertion with "?" marks instead of "%" is 'slightly unfortunate', but in fact it is quite the opposite. If you look further into it (python.org sqlite3 tutorial) there is a part that mentions that sqlite does that in fact to prevent sql injections. So it happens to be a good thing!
